MONDAY DECEMBER 21, 1914.
__________________________________________________
div1.p:
Colonel Goethals Was Not Hampered
By The Canal Commission.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EVENING SUN:

Sir--Just to correct a minor error in
the article on Colonel Goethals in THE
EVENING SUN of today.

The praise given Colonel Goethals for
his work is indeed due. The statement
that the men on the canal--I mean the
men working on the Isthmus--were
working half-heartedly or were doubtful
of success before the Colonel arrived is,
however, I think, erroneous.

The writer's appointment to the Isth-
mus bears date of June 1, 1904, and he
went down on the ship with Mr. Wallace
and Colonel Gorgas, to whose depart-
ment he was attached. He remained on
the Isthmus until the latter part of
1909. During the first few years--and
it was in these that the stress of the
service fell--there were very few white
men, Americans, on the Isthmus whom
he did not know, and, when we were
few, as at first, just to be an American
was to be a friend; and we knew each
other very well. He thinks, then, he
can tell what was the feeling among the
American employes on the Isthmus.
What those in Washington thought he
does not know.

There was some yellow fever in 1905,
especially in May and June--not a great
deal, but it was fairly fatal--and from
some departments there was quite an
exodus from the Isthmus in May and
early June. There was none from our
department; it winnowed out trifling
men, and this was probably an advan-
tage.

Among the men who stayed (and not
many left, and of the great bulk of the
men who came down I can speak with
some knowledge) there was never any
doubt about completing the canal; not
any shadow of doubt. We knew we
would build it if we held on, and we
knew we would hold on.

Yellow fever disappeared for good in
December, 1905, and there was never
any more fear of it. Malaria was con-
trolled, so far as Americans were con-
cerned, by February, 1906, and for all
by the end of the wet season of that
year. After the above date, February,
1906, then, there was no special sick-
ness among the Americans and no fear
of any.

Living conditions, which were some-
what primitive in the beginning, were
quite good, and the people were well sat-
isfied when Mr. Roosevelt visited us in
1906. They were good before Stevens
left. They were improved by Colonel
Goethals, as indeed they had been by
Stevens during his incumbency.

Colonel Goethals came down, if I rec-
ollect aright, in 1907. You imply that
he had difficulty in getting what he
wanted from the commission. This may
have been, but it seems improbable, as
he was chairman of the commission, a
majority of which consisted of his three
subordinate engineers, Gaillard, Sibert
and Rousseau. Colonel Gorgas and Mr.
Blackburn were two other members.
The three engineers came down to the
Isthmus with Colonel Goethals, and
Gorgas was on the Isthmus at the time,
having already been there over three
years. This commission did not stay in
Washington at all.

I am afraid that one sometimes makes
a big thing smaller by claiming for it
more than the truth.

H. R. CARTER, United States Marine Hospital
